dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hey there, and welcome back to "Market Movers," your weekly dose of what's shaking up the financial world.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hey there, and welcome back to Market Movers, your weekly dose of what's shaking up the financial world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's right! And today, A, we've got a really wild story about, uh, Shopify, that e-commerce giant that everyone thought was, like, unstoppable.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's right! And today, A, we've got a really wild story about, uh, Shopify, that e-commerce giant that everyone thought was, like, unstoppable.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? I mean, it's been a tough run for them. Their value just plummeted, what was it, to $84 million last week? Briefly making them, like, the least valuable company in Canada. Oof.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? I mean, it's been a tough run for them. Their value just plummeted, what was it, to eighty four million dollars last week? Briefly making them, like, the least valuable company in Canada. Oof.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its value peaked at $84 billion last week, briefly making it the most valuable company in Canada, and pushing the net worth of its 39-year-old CEO Tobias Lutke north of $6 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and Tobias Lutke, their CEO, his net worth took a serious hit, too. Down south of $6 million. But here's where it gets really, really interesting.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and Tobias Lutke, their C E O, his net worth took a serious hit, too. Down south of six million dollars. But here's where it gets really, really interesting.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...pushing the net worth of its 39-year-old CEO Tobias Lutke north of $6 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: This one early investor, Bessemer Venture Partners, they're calling this whole thing a *triumph*. A *failure* that's a *triumph*? My head hurts.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: This one early investor, Bessemer Venture Partners, they're calling this whole thing a triumph. A failure that's a triumph? My head hurts.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But for one of its earliest investors, San Francisco-based Bessemer Venture Partners, the hype around the company is bittersweet.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: I know, right? So, Bessemer, they put in $5.5 million way back in the initial funding round. And, um, by the time Shopify went public in 2015, their stake was worth half a billion!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know, right? So, Bessemer, they put in five point five million dollars way back in the initial funding round. And, um, by the time Shopify went public in twenty fifteen, their stake was worth half a billion!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The firm first invested $5.5 million in the companys initial funding round, and after additional investments built a 26% stake worth $500 million when it went public in 2015.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Insane returns! But get this, instead of cashing out, which is like, the typical VC move, they *doubled down*. They bought *more* shares.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Insane returns! But get this, instead of cashing out, which is like, the typical V C move, they doubled down. They bought more shares.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...as is the typical modus operandi of venture capital firms hold onto investments while the company scales and cash out following an IPO Bessemer had redistributed all its shares back to its partners by the end of 2018, when the company was worth $15 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, by 2018, when Shopify was worth $15 billion. And today? Uh, that same stake would be, like, $22 million. So, they lost billions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, by twenty eighteen, when Shopify was worth fifteen billion dollars. And today? Uh, that same stake would be, like, twenty two million dollars. So, they lost billions.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Today Bessemers stake would currently be worth close to $22 billion, the firm says.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Billions! The article says they lost at least $17 billion by holding on. So, like, how is this a win?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Billions! The article says they lost at least seventeen billion dollars by holding on. So, like, how is this a win?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By exiting Shopify two years ago, Bessemer left at least $17 billion on the table.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, Alex Ferrara, the Bessemer partner who led that initial round, he said he comprehended they would have this "massive amount of failure." [overlaps] But here’s the kicker.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, Alex Ferrara, the Bessemer partner who led that initial round, he said he comprehended they would have this massive amount of failure. But here's the kicker.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: I couldnt comprehend that they would have this massive amount of success at that time, says Alex Ferrara, the Bessemer partner who led Shopifys initial funding round in 2010.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah! And Professor Will Gornal from UBC, he points out that even with all these losses, for a VC firm, this is actually a huge success story. Because it's common to have built such a small stake in a struggling startup.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah! And Professor Will Gornal from U B C, he points out that even with all these losses, for a V C firm, this is actually a huge success story. Because it's common to have built such a small stake in a struggling startup.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...Bessemers stake in Shopify stands out as a significant missed opportunity in venture investing because it is rare that a venture capital firm would have built such a large stake in a hot startup, says Will Gornal, a professor at the University of British Columbias Sauder Business School.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, even though they lost all that money, the initial return was so massive it still makes the overall investment ridiculously profitable?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, even though they lost all that money, the initial return was so massive it still makes the overall investment ridiculously profitable?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While Bessemers one-time stake in Shopify might prove a once-in-a-lifetime type tech position, Ferrara says the firm will gladly take its realized returns on the deal: between 80x and 100x its initial investment.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. I mean, Ferrara says they'll gladly accept their 'realized losses' on the deal, because it's still between 80 to 100 times their initial investment.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. I mean, Ferrara says they'll gladly accept their realized losses on the deal, because it's still between eighty to one hundred times their initial investment.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Says the venture capitalist: We didnt have a crystal ball. David Jeans, Forbes Staff

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. Just... wow. So, um, COVID-19 played a big role in Shopify's recent struggles, right? Demand for their online tools just dropped.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. Just... wow. So, um, C O V I D-nineteen played a big role in Shopify's recent struggles, right? Demand for their online tools just dropped.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the past month, Shopifys share price has doubled after it generated $470 million in revenue in the first quarter, as demand for its online tools has skyrocketed from brick-and-mortar retailers who have been forced online by the COVID-19 pandemic.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. A lot of those brick-and-mortar retailers that, like, went online during the pandemic just, uh, didn't need the tools as much when things opened up.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. A lot of those brick-and-mortar retailers that, like, went online during the pandemic just, uh, didn't need the tools as much when things opened up.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Meanwhile, you have companies like Zoom just soaring during the pandemic. It’s such a stark contrast in the tech world right now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Meanwhile, you have companies like Zoom just soaring during the pandemic. It's such a stark contrast in the tech world right now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The pandemic boosted the rise of newer arrivals, including Zoom, the video-conferencing firm that is now being used not only to connect office meetings but to hold family gatherings. After going public last year, the San Jose-based firm is now worth $44 billion, almost triple its value at the start of the year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It really is. A weird, weird market. But what a lesson in venture capital, huh?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really is. A weird, weird market. But what a lesson in venture capital, huh?
